Award.AwardTitle: Mechanism and Function of Argonaute 4 Subcellular Localization

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Regulation of gene expression is critical to all cellular processes, from development to environmental response. One way to silence gene expression is by chromatin modifications that prevent transcription. Such transcriptional gene silencing can be induced by small RNAs in association with Argonaute proteins. This presents a conundrum, because by definition, chromatin modification must occur in the nucleus, but many Argonaute proteins are found in the cytoplasm. The role of cytoplasmic accumulation of nuclear-acting Argonaute proteins is unclear, but might reflect regulation of Argonaute action, or relate to transport of small RNAs between cells. This project will exploit the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana to understand the molecular mechanisms that regulate the subcellular localization of small RNA-mediated transcriptional gene silencing, in particular how ARGONAUTE 4 and RNA Polymerase IV-dependent small RNAs are spatially distributed within a cell and how this relates to their functions within and between cells. Because the molecular function of small RNAs and Argonautes are conserved in many species, investigating the localization of ARGONAUTE 4 at the protein, cellular, and organismal levels, this research will create mechanistic paradigms that could be applicable to gene silencing in many species.

Broader Impacts: This research offers outstanding training for a graduate student and a postdoctoral fellow, who will utilize advanced genomic and bioinformatics tools as well as traditional molecular and genetic analyses. An undergraduate student will also be included in the research environment, simultaneously advancing his or her own education and creating mentoring opportunities for the graduate student and postdoctoral fellow. This research will also make fundamental contributions to our understanding of transcriptional gene silencing, an important aspect of gene regulation and a powerful avenue for crop improvement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
RNA Silencing occurs when small RNA molecules direct Argonaute proteins to related sequences in DNA or messenger RNAs. The Argonaute protein then stops (“silences”) the DNA or messenger RNA from carrying out its usual function. RNA Silencing occurs in most organisms, including animals, plants, and fungi. Therefore, researching RNA Silencing in plants has not only led to new approaches in agriculture, but has also led to understanding how RNA Silencing can be used to improve human health.

RNA Silencing typically occurs in the main compartment of a cell (the cytoplasm), where it destroys messenger RNAs after they are made. However, it can also occur in the nucleus, where it modifies the DNA to stop messenger RNA production. These DNA modifications are stable and self-replicating, so this type of RNA Silencing is more robust and long-lasting. My laboratory studies the nuclear form of RNA Silencing, and in this project we focused specifically on Argonaute 4 (AGO4), a protein that binds to small RNAs and triggers RNA Silencing in the nucleus.

We discovered that although AGO4 functions in the nucleus, if it is retained there, it is unstable and cannot sustain its function. AGO4 therefore uses a bipartite nuclear export signal to cycle between the nucleus and the cytoplasm. We also discovered that AGO4 protein is rapidly degraded if it is not bound to small RNA. This occurs whether AGO4 is in the nucleus or the cytoplasm, indicating that there might be two distinct mechanisms to influence AGO4 protein levels. Finally, we investigated how the proteins that AGO4 binds in the nucleus evolve. Although the majority of these proteins are unchanged by evolution, the region that binds to AGO4 is highly variable, suggesting that it experiences unique evolutionary pressure. In addition to publications, this research produced large datasets of small RNAs and transcriptomes that are publically available through the NCBI Short Read Archive.

This grant also supported the careers of young scientists, who were trained in the fields of RNA Silencing, DNA methylation, and Bioinformatics. Trainees on this project included three female high school students, all of whom learned to read scientific literature, carry out experiments, and present their findings in public forums. These young women are now pursuing STEM degrees at university. Four undergraduate students, three graduate students, and one postdoctoral fellows also participated in the project, including two women, one Hispanic-American, and two first-generation college students. Experiential learning experiences such as these are critical when training the diverse array of scientists needed for our economy.
